text: let me just say that the judge has
spoken and I do think it's a tough day
for all of us here in Detroit Detroit is
banging it's like four months ago the
city became the largest in America to
file for bankruptcy and now a federal
judge has cleared the way for Detroit to
try to dig its way out now comes the
hard part it won't be easy and it won't
be painless the problem in three words
too much debt I believe since I came to
office with the crisis that we had this
was inevitable
Detroit is struggling with an estimated
18 billion dollars of debt and other
liabilities it owes roughly half that to
bondholders Wall Street types and
ordinary folks who loaned the city money
and expect it to be paid back in full
the other half of that eighteen billion
represents unfunded pension and
healthcare liabilities for city
employees teachers police officers
firemen no one not investors not city
workers is going to be totally satisfied
as in most bankruptcies creditors are
gonna take a hit the question now is how
big that hit will be and who will feel
the most pain you know as you know we
were being sued almost on a weekly basis
and that's the very thing I had asked I
plead it for not to happen Detroit's
public workers and retirees had hoped to
keep the city out of bankruptcy court
and major creditors like the UAW in the
city's pension funds objected from the
start number two it gives us a forum as
the governor just said to bring all
parties in a significant percentage of
parties that we have to speak to are
unrepresented the retirees they're
worried because Judge Steven Rhodes is
ruling will allow Detroit to cut their
benefits especially their pensions and
city workers should be worried there
appears to be too little money set aside
to cover all the costs and keep in mind
that these days Detroit has roughly
21,000 retired city workers that's
roughly twice as many than who are
actually working
so now Detroit will move ahead with
proposals
to restructure its debt maybe pushing
some payments to bondholders further
into the future we'll know more in a few
weeks but the plan is expected to
include controversial cuts to unsecured
creditors the ones lower in the pecking
order and the city could spin off its
water and sewer departments and even
sell property belonging to the Detroit
Institute of Arts
now creditors are likely to appeal but
it's unlikely that Tuesday's ruling will
be overturned there's one thing that
everyone agrees on is that Detroit is in
big trouble
while we were very pleased we remain
very concerned about the need to adjust
the city's debt to improve its level of
services for his citizens and to also
prepare for the city to exit this
receivership in a fashion that restores
democracy to the city
